topics.title: Introduction and performance marketing definitions
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Timothy and frames the episode. They define performance marketing vs. paid growth, clarify what counts as “paid” (online/offline/affiliates), and anchor performance marketing as measurable marketing.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for BuildBetter and OneSchema, including product overviews and use cases.

topics.title: Is paid growth for every company?
topics.summary: Timothy argues “paid is for everyone,” emphasizing platforms becoming pay-to-play. He recommends paid search as a baseline channel because it’s user-intent driven, while social/video are more disruptive and context-dependent.

topics.title: When paid can be the primary growth engine
topics.summary: They discuss how to tell if paid could drive most growth by analyzing where users already come from and “turning the knob up.” Timothy shares an example (Hairstory/IPSY) and warns that creative doesn’t transfer cleanly across platforms due to different user mindsets.

topics.title: Running “signs of life” tests on channels
topics.summary: Timothy explains lightweight “signs of life” experiments: start small, validate signal, then build proper campaigns rather than scaling immediately. He recommends starting with first-party data and tight lookalikes (e.g., 1%) before broadening.

topics.title: Diagnosing failures: targeting, creative, and measurement
topics.summary: They cover how to interpret early metrics (e.g., CTR) to separate targeting issues from creative issues, and why qualitative feedback (focus groups) can be necessary. Timothy also discusses control-vs-test creative setups and the limits of platform metrics.

topics.title: Test duration, budget constraints, and projections
topics.summary: Timothy explains that ideal test length is driven by statistical relevance but usually constrained by budget. He suggests using small-test results to model expected returns at higher spend with partner input (Meta/Google reps).

topics.title: Experimentation mindset and platform differences
topics.summary: Timothy advises teams to expect failures and treat them as learning, since each platform’s behavior and mechanics differ. He emphasizes creating a culture where experimentation is safe and iterative.

topics.title: Which platforms to prioritize and why
topics.summary: Timothy recommends starting with Google Search, then Meta, and adding YouTube if you can sustain a video-creative refresh flywheel; TikTok depends on existing audience signals. He notes LinkedIn’s high costs but powerful targeting, best for high-LTV/enterprise use cases.

topics.title: What makes YouTube video ads work
topics.summary: Timothy shares creative guidance for YouTube: start with emotion (comedy, happiness, etc.) to create memorability and downstream action. He reiterates the need for consistent creative refresh to keep performance strong.

topics.title: Emerging channels: podcasts, CTV, VR, AI ads
topics.summary: They discuss newer opportunities beyond core platforms, including podcasts and connected TV (when measured well), plus early-stage areas like VR and AI advertising. Timothy prefers learning from others’ experiments before investing heavily.

topics.title: When to start paid and scaling considerations
topics.summary: Timothy explains timing depends on goals and market demand: paid can drive immediate results while SEO takes time. He contrasts demand-capture (search, competitor bidding) with demand-creation (display) using a hotel “romantic setup” example.

topics.title: Paid before product-market fit risks
topics.summary: They discuss why heavy paid spend pre-PMF can backfire if operational/product constraints prevent conversion (IBM in Africa currency example). Timothy advises ensuring conversion readiness to avoid wasted spend and brand damage.

topics.title: Why agencies underperform and how to use them
topics.summary: Timothy explains agencies often rely on copy-paste playbooks and lack time for deep account work (landing pages, UX, full ops cadence). He recommends agencies/consultants for getting started, with clear milestones to hire in-house and red flags if partners resist that plan.

topics.title: First in-house hire: signal vs noise mindset
topics.summary: Timothy describes hiring for analytical thinking over channel-specific skills, emphasizing the ability to identify the right metrics for the campaign goal. He ties this to his baseball stats background and shares an interview approach that tests prioritization under data overload.
